body:
When reviewing the fix of #88327, I feel that #88331 as well as existing schedulerQueue unit tests are not written in a desired way.

The racing cause of #88327 lies on concurrent access of private fields - those private fields are protected by locks via public functions, but unfortunately directly accessed by the unit tests (under the same package). To dive deeper, it's because the `PriorityQueue` is created and **run immediately**:

https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/blob/de66c643c479f420b1902f8897636ea41ac2b3c3/pkg/scheduler/internal/queue/scheduling_queue_test.go#L1511-L1515

In this way, the unit tests risk us into a situation that two goroutines in `q.Run()` may race with the unit test's calling on private fields/functions.

But, IMO we shouldn't run the flushXYZ() functions **_unconditionally_** for each unit test. Instead, unit tests should be adopting a clear programming model to know what exactly is being tested:

- if it's intended to test the racing with flushXYZ(), we should build dedicated unit tests **without** accessing private fields/functions (or integration tests).
- otherwise, which I think is the common case, don't run the two async flushXYZ() functions; if they have to be called, compose a case by leveraging `FakeClock` and call flushXYZ() explicitly (see [example](https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/blob/de66c643c479f420b1902f8897636ea41ac2b3c3/pkg/scheduler/internal/queue/scheduling_queue_test.go#L1075-L1078)).

/sig scheduling
/cleanup
